content: Act quickly to clean the stain. The longer a stain is allowed to sit on your nice tablecloth or summer dress, the harder it will be to get out. Whether a stain is from food or ink or anything else, drawing it out from linens will work best when it hasn't yet dried. Some older stains require dry cleaning to be removed. Dry cleaning can ruin linens so it’s imperative that you try and treat stains quickly so that you don’t have to resort to harsher methods to remove the stain. Scrape off excess liquid or solids. Use a flat butter knife or spoon to gently lift off any residue. For example, jelly can be scooped up with a spoon so that there’s less of a mess to clean up. You want to remove as much of the substance as possible before beginning to treat the stain. [1] Do not squeeze or press the linen or stain. Doing so may grind the stain substance into the fibers of the linen and make it harder to get out. You can gently shake off residual liquids like wine or juice instead of wringing them out. Blot the stain with a white cloth or towel. Gently dab up and down with a paper towel, for example, to lift the stain from your linens to the towel. Work from the outside of the stain’s perimeter to the inside. This will prevent the pressure of blotting from spreading the stain. [2] Apply a chemical solution to the stain. For best results, use a specific product for removing stains rather than regular soap. A chemical reaction is an efficient way of removing stains from your linens. Lay out your linen and place a few paper towels or rag clothes underneath to catch excess liquid. Sprinkle baking soda on the stain and add a few drops at a time of vinegar. Blot the stain with a paper towel to soak up the moisture. Lemon juice will help whiten any dingy materials. Squeeze some juice onto a stain or discolored linen item and let it sit until you see it begin to lighten, and then rinse it out. You can also buy a stain treatment to apply to the stain like Tide or Oxyclean. Don't even rub a stain. Rubbing and applying too much pressure will help a stain to set into the linen rather than get it out. Fill a sink with hot water. Let the faucet run long enough to fill a sink, bathtub, or washing machine with enough water to cover the linens you’re washing. Hot water should only be used with an additive to help lift the stain. Heat makes stains settle into the fabric so make sure you’re adding another ingredient to the water. [3] Add another cleanser to the water. Because hot water alone is detrimental to proper stain removal, you need to pair it with another cleanser. You can either purchase a specific stain removal product or make your own with household items. An example stain removing recipe is as follows: 1 scoop of Oxyclean, 1 cup of Biz, ¾ cup of ammonia, and a gallon of hot water. [4] White vinegar will help to cut grease as well. Use an ⅛ to a ½ cup based on how big your load of laundry is. [5] A mild dish detergent will work well too. Use a quarter to a full cup of detergent depending on how much you’re washing. [6] Submerge your linen items in the sink. Make sure the fabric is completely saturated and under water. Let the material soak for at least an hour or overnight. Every once in a while, stir the water with a wooden spoon to agitate the water and make sure the solution is dispersed well. Drain the sink and wash your linen items normally. Put them on a gentle cycle in the washing machine and not in hot water so that the delicate fibers aren’t ruined. You can add more white vinegar, Oxyclean, or mild dish detergent to the load to help fight stubborn stains. Hang to dry. Your dryer is another heat source that could cause a stain to set into the linen. Instead, air or line dry the fabrics so that you don’t undo your progress after soaking them. Hanging linens to dry also helps minimize wrinkles. Soak the linen item in a hot water bath with a stain treatment additive. Before going to any additional methods, try removing a stain the same way you would with a new stain. You may be able to get rid of the stain by simply soaking the fabric and then machine or hand washing it. If linen items are stored improperly or are put away with existing stains, it may be more difficult to remove the stains. Fill up a bathtub or sink with cool water for soaking. Hot water needs an added cleanser to prevent stains from setting. Every once in a while, check on the stain to see if it is being absorbed into the water. To test the stain, lightly rub the material between your fingers to see if it's coming out. Be gentle so that you don't rub the stain into the fabric. Lay out the linen items in the sun. If the stains persist through multiple soakings and washing, let the fabric sit in the sun for a few hours. Sunlight can also damage fabric and bleach too much, so it’s important to keep an eye out if your fabric begins to look too light. Remove your linens from the sun if they begin to fade beyond the original color. You can put the linens out completely dry, or you can lightly mist them with a spray bottle filled with water, non-chlorine bleach, or any other liquid stain remover. [7] Do not soak the fabric if you’re leaving it in the sun. It may create an unpleasant odor. Vintage fabrics may become damaged from direct sunlight so use caution when deciding whether or not to put antiques in sunlight. Press older linen items by ironing immediately after washing to preserve them. It’s best to iron linen while it’s slightly damp. Once you have successfully removed a stain, you can safely apply heat to any of your linen items. Use the proper setting on your iron so that you don't cause any damage. By pressing fabric, it is then easier to store and less susceptible to damage and wrinkling. Ironing a stain is a perfect way to seal the stain into the fibers. Check your whole garment or fabric to make sure that there are no other hidden stains. Hang dry the linen if ironing is not needed. No matter the age of a stain, putting linens that have been rescued from stains in the dryer is not advised. Use a drying rack, clothesline with clothespins, or a clothes rack to air out your linens. Dab fresh lemon juice onto a new stain. Apply fresh lemon juice to the stain and sprinkle salt over top. Let the linens sit in the sun for several hours before washing. Check on it periodically to make sure the stain is beginning to fade. If it is not, add more juice and salt. [8] Be careful on bright, sunny days because the sun could lighten your linen items very quickly. Set a timer to check on the progress so that you don't end up with splotchy fabric. For difficult stains, repeat this process several times. Wash the fabric in between repetitions. For large stains or dingy white tablecloths for example, combine lemon juice and dissolved salt in a spray bottle and lightly spray the whole thing. Let it sit in the sun laid out flat so that the effect is uniform. Absorb new stains with a baking soda mixture. Make a baking soda paste with 4 tablespoons (59.1 ml) of baking soda mixed with equal amounts water. Mix and apply gently so you don't rub the paste into the stain. After the paste has dried and sat for about 15 to 30 minutes, scrape off any excess paste before washing the linens normally. [9] Treat oil stains with cornstarch. Oils stains are some of the most difficult to get out of fabrics. Sprinkle cornstarch on the stain and waiting 15 minutes for it to set. Then, scrape the starch off. Wash the linens in a sink bath with some dish washing soap or in the washing machine at a gentle cycle. [10] Don't coat the stain in too much cornstarch. You only need a small coating to absorb the stain. You can reapply another coat after the first one if the stain persists. If you need to rinse the cornstarch out, use cool water to keep the stain from sticking around.

<p>Linen is a delicate fabric with fibers that can become easily damaged by stains. Special care is required to remove stains from linen so that the table cloth, fancy napkins, summer dress, or whatever you're trying to clean is not damaged. Stain removal is a simple process that will keep your linens looking clean and new.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Removing_New_Stains_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Removing_New_Stains">Removing New Stains</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-1.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-1.jpg" height="484" id="img_feaf9f3c0a" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_feaf9f3c0a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-1.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Act quickly to clean the stain.</b> The longer a stain is allowed to sit on your nice tablecloth or summer dress, the harder it will be to get out. Whether a stain is from food or ink or anything else, drawing it out from linens will work best when it hasn't yet dried.

<ul>
<li>Some older stains require dry cleaning to be removed.</li>
<li>Dry cleaning can ruin linens so it’s imperative that you try and treat stains quickly so that you don’t have to resort to harsher methods to remove the stain.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-2.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-2.jpg" height="484" id="img_9c5a0f9a4b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9c5a0f9a4b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-2.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Scrape off excess liquid or solids.</b> Use a flat butter knife or spoon to gently lift off any residue. For example, jelly can be scooped up with a spoon so that there’s less of a mess to clean up. You want to remove as much of the substance as possible before beginning to treat the stain.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Do not squeeze or press the linen or stain. Doing so may grind the stain substance into the fibers of the linen and make it harder to get out.</li>
<li>You can gently shake off residual liquids like wine or juice instead of wringing them out.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-3.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-3.jpg" height="484" id="img_080bc7d0fe" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_080bc7d0fe')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-3.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Blot the stain with a white cloth or towel.</b> Gently dab up and down with a paper towel, for example, to lift the stain from your linens to the towel. Work from the outside of the stain’s perimeter to the inside. This will prevent the pressure of blotting from spreading the stain.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-4.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-4.jpg" height="484" id="img_54fcd76785" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_54fcd76785')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-4.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Apply a chemical solution to the stain.</b> For best results, use a specific product for removing stains rather than regular soap. A chemical reaction is an efficient way of removing stains from your linens. Lay out your linen and place a few paper towels or rag clothes underneath to catch excess liquid.

<ul>
<li>Sprinkle baking soda on the stain and add a few drops at a time of vinegar. Blot the stain with a paper towel to soak up the moisture.</li>
<li>Lemon juice will help whiten any dingy materials. Squeeze some juice onto a stain or discolored linen item and let it sit until you see it begin to lighten, and then rinse it out.</li>
<li>You can also buy a stain treatment to apply to the stain like Tide or Oxyclean.</li>
<li>Don't even rub a stain. Rubbing and applying too much pressure will help a stain to set into the linen rather than get it out.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-5.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-5.jpg" height="466" id="img_df237b6549" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_df237b6549')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="466" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-5.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Fill a sink with hot water.</b> Let the faucet run long enough to fill a sink, bathtub, or washing machine with enough water to cover the linens you’re washing. Hot water should only be used with an additive to help lift the stain. Heat makes stains settle into the fabric so make sure you’re adding another ingredient to the water.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-6.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-6.jpg" height="484" id="img_98dcc8a35f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_98dcc8a35f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-6.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add another cleanser to the water.</b> Because hot water alone is detrimental to proper stain removal, you need to pair it with another cleanser. You can either purchase a specific stain removal product or make your own with household items.

<ul>
<li>An example stain removing recipe is as follows: 1 scoop of Oxyclean, 1 cup of Biz, ¾ cup of ammonia, and a gallon of hot water.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>White vinegar will help to cut grease as well. Use an ⅛ to a ½ cup based on how big your load of laundry is.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>A mild dish detergent will work well too. Use a quarter to a full cup of detergent depending on how much you’re washing. <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-7.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-7.jpg" height="475" id="img_13fa67a663" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_13fa67a663')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="475" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-7.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Submerge your linen items in the sink.</b> Make sure the fabric is completely saturated and under water. Let the material soak for at least an hour or overnight. Every once in a while, stir the water with a wooden spoon to agitate the water and make sure the solution is dispersed well.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-8.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-8.jpg" height="484" id="img_499ed44e07" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_499ed44e07')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-8.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 8" class="step_num">8</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_8"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Drain the sink and wash your linen items normally.</b> Put them on a gentle cycle in the washing machine and not in hot water so that the delicate fibers aren’t ruined. You can add more white vinegar, Oxyclean, or mild dish detergent to the load to help fight stubborn stains.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-9.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-9.jpg" height="484" id="img_a9f34918bf" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a9f34918bf')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-9.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 9" class="step_num">9</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_9"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Hang to dry.</b> Your dryer is another heat source that could cause a stain to set into the linen. Instead, air or line dry the fabrics so that you don’t undo your progress after soaking them. Hanging linens to dry also helps minimize wrinkles.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Treating_Old_Stains_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Treating_Old_Stains">Treating Old Stains</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1b/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-10.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-10.jpg" height="472" id="img_b0ffc0cdb6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b0ffc0cdb6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="472" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1b/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-10.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Soak the linen item in a hot water bath with a stain treatment additive.</b> Before going to any additional methods, try removing a stain the same way you would with a new stain. You may be able to get rid of the stain by simply soaking the fabric and then machine or hand washing it. If linen items are stored improperly or are put away with existing stains, it may be more difficult to remove the stains.

<ul>
<li>Fill up a bathtub or sink with cool water for soaking. Hot water needs an added cleanser to prevent stains from setting.</li>
<li>Every once in a while, check on the stain to see if it is being absorbed into the water.</li>
<li>To test the stain, lightly rub the material between your fingers to see if it's coming out. Be gentle so that you don't rub the stain into the fabric.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-11.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-11.jpg" height="484" id="img_4f9744eb4e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4f9744eb4e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-11.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Lay out the linen items in the sun.</b> If the stains persist through multiple soakings and washing, let the fabric sit in the sun for a few hours. Sunlight can also damage fabric and bleach too much, so it’s important to keep an eye out if your fabric begins to look too light. Remove your linens from the sun if they begin to fade beyond the original color.

<ul>
<li>You can put the linens out completely dry, or you can lightly mist them with a spray bottle filled with water, non-chlorine bleach, or any other liquid stain remover.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Do not soak the fabric if you’re leaving it in the sun. It may create an unpleasant odor.</li>
<li>Vintage fabrics may become damaged from direct sunlight so use caution when deciding whether or not to put antiques in sunlight.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-12.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-12.jpg" height="484" id="img_1bfef5531f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1bfef5531f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-12.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Press older linen items by ironing immediately after washing to preserve them.</b> It’s best to iron linen while it’s slightly damp. Once you have successfully removed a stain, you can safely apply heat to any of your linen items. Use the proper setting on your iron so that you don't cause any damage. By pressing fabric, it is then easier to store and less susceptible to damage and wrinkling.

<ul>
<li>Ironing a stain is a perfect way to seal the stain into the fibers.</li>
<li>Check your whole garment or fabric to make sure that there are no other hidden stains.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-13.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-13.jpg" height="484" id="img_9f1d1fb1eb" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9f1d1fb1eb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-13.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Hang dry the linen if ironing is not needed.</b> No matter the age of a stain, putting linens that have been rescued from stains in the dryer is not advised. Use a drying rack, clothesline with clothespins, or a clothes rack to air out your linens.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">

<a class="anchor" name="Using_Household_Items_to_Treat_Stains_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_Household_Items_to_Treat_Stains">Using Household Items to Treat Stains</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-14.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-14.jpg" height="484" id="img_816d756ac9" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_816d756ac9')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-14.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Dab fresh lemon juice onto a new stain.</b> Apply fresh lemon juice to the stain and sprinkle salt over top. Let the linens sit in the sun for several hours before washing. Check on it periodically to make sure the stain is beginning to fade. If it is not, add more juice and salt. <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Be careful on bright, sunny days because the sun could lighten your linen items very quickly. Set a timer to check on the progress so that you don't end up with splotchy fabric.</li>
<li>For difficult stains, repeat this process several times. Wash the fabric in between repetitions.</li>
<li>For large stains or dingy white tablecloths for example, combine lemon juice and dissolved salt in a spray bottle and lightly spray the whole thing. Let it sit in the sun laid out flat so that the effect is uniform.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-15.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-15.jpg" height="484" id="img_ffa610c88a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ffa610c88a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-15.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Absorb new stains with a baking soda mixture.</b> Make a baking soda paste with 4 tablespoons (59.1 ml) of baking soda mixed with equal amounts water. Mix and apply gently so you don't rub the paste into the stain. After the paste has dried and sat for about 15 to 30 minutes, scrape off any excess paste before washing the linens normally.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=458441" href="#/Image:Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-16.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-16.jpg" height="484" id="img_8a653a25f3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8a653a25f3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove Spots from Linen Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="484" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-16.jpg/aid458441-v4-728px-Remove-Spots-from-Linen-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Treat oil stains with cornstarch.</b> Oils stains are some of the most difficult to get out of fabrics. Sprinkle cornstarch on the stain and waiting 15 minutes for it to set. Then, scrape the starch off. Wash the linens in a sink bath with some dish washing soap or in the washing machine at a gentle cycle.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Don't coat the stain in too much cornstarch. You only need a small coating to absorb the stain. You can reapply another coat after the first one if the stain persists.</li>
<li>If you need to rinse the cornstarch out, use cool water to keep the stain from sticking around.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

</h2>

<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="373102" data-caid="373975" data-cqid="373119" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2033423" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do l remove a foundation stain from linen?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Apply a baking soda, hydrogen peroxide, and vinegar solution to the foundation spot and scrub the area with a toothbrush. Let it sit for 24 hours, then wash the linen as usual in the washing machine.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

</div>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="471669" data-caid="472542" data-cqid="471686" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2138295" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="2">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">A linen jacquard table cloth has stains I found after being dry cleaned and stored for several years. I don't know if it was a water stain, or tea or coffee. Can it be removed?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Yes, it should be able to be cleaned with following the steps in this article. Follow the second part of the article about treating old stains. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="33174" data-caid="34047" data-cqid="33191" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="249491" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="3" data-votes_up="4">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I have linen curtains that have a water stain. I had them dry cleaned and the stain is still there help!</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Sometimes a stain can come out just by soaking or letting it fade, depending on the stain and the material. Check to see if your curtains can get wet, and try soaking them in a warm bath in the tub or a sink with a cup of white vinegar. Rinse it out and try again if the stain persists. </div>

title: How to Remove Spots from Linen
content_html:
Act quickly to clean the stain. The longer a stain is allowed to sit on your nice tablecloth or summer dress, the harder it will be to get out. Whether a stain is from food or ink or anything else, drawing it out from linens will work best when it hasn't yet dried.
  • Some older stains require dry cleaning to be removed.
  • Dry cleaning can ruin linens so it’s imperative that you try and treat stains quickly so that you don’t have to resort to harsher methods to remove the stain.
Scrape off excess liquid or solids. Use a flat butter knife or spoon to gently lift off any residue. For example, jelly can be scooped up with a spoon so that there’s less of a mess to clean up. You want to remove as much of the substance as possible before beginning to treat the stain.[1]
  • Do not squeeze or press the linen or stain. Doing so may grind the stain substance into the fibers of the linen and make it harder to get out.
  • You can gently shake off residual liquids like wine or juice instead of wringing them out.
Blot the stain with a white cloth or towel. Gently dab up and down with a paper towel, for example, to lift the stain from your linens to the towel. Work from the outside of the stain’s perimeter to the inside. This will prevent the pressure of blotting from spreading the stain.[2]
Apply a chemical solution to the stain. For best results, use a specific product for removing stains rather than regular soap. A chemical reaction is an efficient way of removing stains from your linens. Lay out your linen and place a few paper towels or rag clothes underneath to catch excess liquid.
  • Sprinkle baking soda on the stain and add a few drops at a time of vinegar. Blot the stain with a paper towel to soak up the moisture.
  • Lemon juice will help whiten any dingy materials. Squeeze some juice onto a stain or discolored linen item and let it sit until you see it begin to lighten, and then rinse it out.
  • You can also buy a stain treatment to apply to the stain like Tide or Oxyclean.
  • Don't even rub a stain. Rubbing and applying too much pressure will help a stain to set into the linen rather than get it out.
Fill a sink with hot water. Let the faucet run long enough to fill a sink, bathtub, or washing machine with enough water to cover the linens you’re washing. Hot water should only be used with an additive to help lift the stain. Heat makes stains settle into the fabric so make sure you’re adding another ingredient to the water.[3]
Add another cleanser to the water. Because hot water alone is detrimental to proper stain removal, you need to pair it with another cleanser. You can either purchase a specific stain removal product or make your own with household items.
  • An example stain removing recipe is as follows: 1 scoop of Oxyclean, 1 cup of Biz, ¾ cup of ammonia, and a gallon of hot water.[4]
  • White vinegar will help to cut grease as well. Use an ⅛ to a ½ cup based on how big your load of laundry is.[5]
  • A mild dish detergent will work well too. Use a quarter to a full cup of detergent depending on how much you’re washing. [6]
Submerge your linen items in the sink. Make sure the fabric is completely saturated and under water. Let the material soak for at least an hour or overnight. Every once in a while, stir the water with a wooden spoon to agitate the water and make sure the solution is dispersed well.
Drain the sink and wash your linen items normally. Put them on a gentle cycle in the washing machine and not in hot water so that the delicate fibers aren’t ruined. You can add more white vinegar, Oxyclean, or mild dish detergent to the load to help fight stubborn stains.
Hang to dry. Your dryer is another heat source that could cause a stain to set into the linen. Instead, air or line dry the fabrics so that you don’t undo your progress after soaking them. Hanging linens to dry also helps minimize wrinkles.
Soak the linen item in a hot water bath with a stain treatment additive. Before going to any additional methods, try removing a stain the same way you would with a new stain. You may be able to get rid of the stain by simply soaking the fabric and then machine or hand washing it. If linen items are stored improperly or are put away with existing stains, it may be more difficult to remove the stains.
  • Fill up a bathtub or sink with cool water for soaking. Hot water needs an added cleanser to prevent stains from setting.
  • Every once in a while, check on the stain to see if it is being absorbed into the water.
  • To test the stain, lightly rub the material between your fingers to see if it's coming out. Be gentle so that you don't rub the stain into the fabric.
Lay out the linen items in the sun. If the stains persist through multiple soakings and washing, let the fabric sit in the sun for a few hours. Sunlight can also damage fabric and bleach too much, so it’s important to keep an eye out if your fabric begins to look too light. Remove your linens from the sun if they begin to fade beyond the original color.
  • You can put the linens out completely dry, or you can lightly mist them with a spray bottle filled with water, non-chlorine bleach, or any other liquid stain remover.[7]
  • Do not soak the fabric if you’re leaving it in the sun. It may create an unpleasant odor.
  • Vintage fabrics may become damaged from direct sunlight so use caution when deciding whether or not to put antiques in sunlight.
Press older linen items by ironing immediately after washing to preserve them. It’s best to iron linen while it’s slightly damp. Once you have successfully removed a stain, you can safely apply heat to any of your linen items. Use the proper setting on your iron so that you don't cause any damage. By pressing fabric, it is then easier to store and less susceptible to damage and wrinkling.
  • Ironing a stain is a perfect way to seal the stain into the fibers.
  • Check your whole garment or fabric to make sure that there are no other hidden stains.
Hang dry the linen if ironing is not needed. No matter the age of a stain, putting linens that have been rescued from stains in the dryer is not advised. Use a drying rack, clothesline with clothespins, or a clothes rack to air out your linens.
Dab fresh lemon juice onto a new stain. Apply fresh lemon juice to the stain and sprinkle salt over top. Let the linens sit in the sun for several hours before washing. Check on it periodically to make sure the stain is beginning to fade. If it is not, add more juice and salt. [8]
  • Be careful on bright, sunny days because the sun could lighten your linen items very quickly. Set a timer to check on the progress so that you don't end up with splotchy fabric.
  • For difficult stains, repeat this process several times. Wash the fabric in between repetitions.
  • For large stains or dingy white tablecloths for example, combine lemon juice and dissolved salt in a spray bottle and lightly spray the whole thing. Let it sit in the sun laid out flat so that the effect is uniform.
Absorb new stains with a baking soda mixture. Make a baking soda paste with 4 tablespoons (59.1 ml) of baking soda mixed with equal amounts water. Mix and apply gently so you don't rub the paste into the stain. After the paste has dried and sat for about 15 to 30 minutes, scrape off any excess paste before washing the linens normally.[9]
Treat oil stains with cornstarch. Oils stains are some of the most difficult to get out of fabrics. Sprinkle cornstarch on the stain and waiting 15 minutes for it to set. Then, scrape the starch off. Wash the linens in a sink bath with some dish washing soap or in the washing machine at a gentle cycle.[10]
  • Don't coat the stain in too much cornstarch. You only need a small coating to absorb the stain. You can reapply another coat after the first one if the stain persists.
  • If you need to rinse the cornstarch out, use cool water to keep the stain from sticking around.
